    "notes": "1. Does not include any client contingency

    "problem": "Essential Remedial works are required to the NHBR Kyndryl Generators,
which supports Kyndryl internal and external clients.This project is for the full top-end overhaul and radiator replacement on HV Generator 4 plus weather-proofing of the enclosures for HV Generators 1, 2 and 4.",
    "scope": "[2:06 PM] Jowett, Paul @ Sale
Scope of WorksProblem Statement:Essential Remedial works are required to the NHBR Kyndryl Generators,
which supports Kyndryl internal and external clients.This project is for the full top-end overhaul and radiator replacement on HV Generator 4 plus weather-proofing of the enclosures for HV Generators 1, 2 and 4.Scope of Works: The following items are to be delivered as a minimum to satisfy the aims of this project:
All works to be completed in accordance with  Kyndryl Change Control approvals and are subject to IBM / Kyndryl Change Freeze windows.
 CBRE BP 19 applies for the Project Management delivery.
All work is to be performed as per CBRE reviewed and approved contractor Method Statements.
Relevant CBRE Field Switching Procedures to be approved prior to execution of the works.
Generators 1, 2 & 4 enclosure weather-proofing solution to be warranted for a minimum of 5 years.
Generators 1, 2 & 4 enclosure weather-proofing solution to include up to 100mm (or maximum allowable) of all penetration/service points through the enclosure roofs.
Generators 1, 2 & 4 enclosure weather-proofing solution to be able to withstand the temperatures experienced at the enclosure roofs while the engine is running eg: Generator exhaust heat. Will be subject to heat tests and check
Generator 4
Remove the existing roof mounted radiator cooling system. Crane hire and scaffolding to be included.
Strip and remove the major Generator components (including cylinder heads) for overhaul. NOTE: The enclosure roof may require removal to enable the head and top-end removal works to be completed. If any concerns reference the structural integrity of the enclosure
 are identified due to the level of corrosion, enclosure to be replaced.
Replacement Generator enclosure (if required) to provide the following:
· Existing SWA electrical supply to the enclosure to be tested before re-use
· fuel leak detection and fuel leak containment if disconnected for the works, retest if fitted
· any changes required to feed new equipment on the Roof Radiator will be rested from local auxiliary distribution boards (the existing is 1x 8-way 125A TP&N distribution panel to support the power equipment associated with the Generator (radiator fans etc)
 and 1x 6-way 63A SP&N for the small power equipment serving the Generator enclosure (local lighting and enclosure heating, controls, auxiliary supplies, starter batteries & battery charger etc).

    "scope": "To supply labour and materials necessary to undertake the following works: 
Attend site prior to tank refurb to drain the tank & isolate the fire pump so work can commence
Return visit required to re-instate the pumps & put the system back online

Geotextile protective matting liner underlay. 
Butyl rubber liner and associated fittings *(See guarantee details). 
New galvanised steel zed-purlins. 
Direct acting contents gauge connection. 
3kw Immersion heater. 
250mm dia. Internal suction pipework c/w vortex inhibitor. 
100mm dia. Internal overflow pipework. 
50mm dia. Cast iron equilibrium ball float valve.

    "scope": "This is a 4-week programme of works to run alongside the separately funded HV Maintenance & associated HV Transformer maintenance. 3rd party specialist (Enerveo) to attend each week on days 2 and 3.

Corrosion can cause serious problems in a cooling tower, including:

Debris: Corrosion can result in metal debris entering the water system, contaminating the water, blocking pipes and causing inefficient cooling processes. 
Leaks: Corroded metal can create small holes within the system, exposing the closed water system to the outside. This can result in water leaking from the cooling tower or biological contaminants entering the system.

    "problem": "The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 1A the bearings on the single fan section blade have broken down. If this fan fails the tower will have to be shut down until repaired. If we do not carry out the works it could result in the resilience of phase 1 site cooling to be at risk",
    "scope": "•\tTower will receive a pre-disinfection dose directly to the tower sump -0.5 litres of both ABT1 & ABT2. Tower pre-disinfection will be for 1 hour, minimum 
•\tABT1 & ABT2 levels are to be monitored and logged on the service report sheet. When an acceptable level has been achieved, these details are also recorded on the dynamic risk assessment service report sheet
•\tCBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will then make the necessary electrical isolations as per the approved FSP
•\tCBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will manually isolate the flow and return water valves positioned on the tower sump and on the return pipework on the top inspection platform. CBRE with WCS Group technicians in attendance will also isolate the Mains Water inlet valve to stop tower from filling
•\tThe Tower will then be drained to the dedicated foul drain using the drain off valve and sump pump
•\tThe faulty fan will then be stripped down and replaced with new fan shafts and bearings.
•\tOn completion of the fan repair, the other 2 fans on cooling tower 1A will be inspected for damage and where necessary, advise replacement.
•\tAfter repair to the fan has been completed on the tower, Baltimore Air Coil technicians will, where applied, remove their locks and clasps and CBRE will run the fans and make sure all is ok. Once happy the tower shall be filled back to it’s appropriate levels.
•\tThe circulating water will be tested for bromine, ABT1 and ABT2 will be added to boost the level above 100ppm, the bromine level will be monitored every 15 minutes
•\tOnce acceptable the tower will be dosed with commissioning dose of inhibitor
•\tOn completion of the Tower post-disinfection CBRE will be informed so we can reinstate the electrical supply to the fans and pumps then sign off the permit to work relating to the Tower",
    "justification": "If Cooling Tower 1A - single fan is not replaced this could impact the resilience of cooling for phase 1",

The problem statement indicates: The cooling towers have 3 fan sections in total with 2 fans on each section. On Cooling tower 1A the bearings on the single fan section blade have broken down. The defined scope of work includes: •\tTower will receive a pre-disinfection dose directly to the tower sump -0.5 litres of both ABT1 & ABT2. Tower pre-disinfection will be for 1 hour, minimum 
•\tABT1 & ABT2 levels are to be monitored and logged on the service report sheet. When an acceptable level has been achieved, these details are also recorded on the dynamic risk assessment service report sheet
•\tCBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will then make the necessary electrical isolations as per the approved FSP
•\tCBRE with Baltimore Air Coil technicians in attendance will manually isolate the flow and return water valves positioned on the tower sump and on the return pipework on the top inspection platform. CBRE with WCS Group technicians in attendance will also isolate the Mains Water inlet valve to stop tower from filling
•\tThe Tower will then be drained to the dedicated foul drain using the drain off valve and sump pump
•\tThe faulty fan will then be stripped down and replaced with new fan shafts and bearings.
•\tOn completion of the fan repair, the other 2 fans on cooling tower 1A will be inspected for damage and where necessary, advise replacement.
•\tAfter repair to the fan has been completed on the tower, Baltimore Air Coil technicians will, where applied, remove their locks and clasps and CBRE will run the fans and make sure all is ok. Once happy the tower shall be filled back to it’s appropriate levels.
•\tThe circulating water will be tested for bromine, ABT1 and ABT2 will be added to boost the level above 100ppm, the bromine level will be monitored every 15 minutes
•\tOnce acceptable the tower will be dosed with commissioning dose of inhibitor
•\tOn completion of the Tower post-disinfection CBRE will be informed so we can reinstate the electrical supply to the fans and pumps then sign off the permit to work relating to the Tower. The justification provided is: If Cooling Tower 1A - single fan is not replaced this could impact the resilience of cooling for phase 1. If not approved, the effect would be: If Cooling Tower 1A - single fan is not replaced this could impact the resilience of cooling for phase 1.",

    "problem": "STREAMLINED ENERGY AND CARBON REPORTING (SECR)

What is it and why?
  • The result of UK government consultation to simplify carbon reporting for large companies, following closure of UK CRC scheme (in 2019)
  • SECR aims to ‘streamline’ and standardise Carbon Reporting and Accounting across large businesses
  • Expands upon 2013 amendment to the Companies Act 2006 (Strategic Report and Directors’ Report) Regulations, in line with Mandatory GHG Reporting

Who is captured?
 SECR requirements apply to all:
  • UK quoted companies
  • UK registered, unquoted large companies, defined as:
                         o At least 250 employees
                         o Annual turnover greater than £36m
                         o Annual balance sheet total greater than £18m
  • Large Limited Liability Partnerships (LLPs)
  • Large unregistered companies

What must these large companies report upon?
  From financial years beginning on or after 1st April 2019, qualifying large UK companies will need to include the following information within (or alongside) their Directors’ Report annually:
  • GHG emissions (at the very minimum covering all electricity, gas and transport use), with inclusion of an intensity ratio
  • Total MWh energy use, whenever practical, in a format that can be compared with results from previous years
  • Information about energy efficiency actions undertaken during the reporting period",
